review.title: Automated Reasoning and Presentation Support for Formalizing Mathematics in Mizar
review.abstract: This paper presents a combination of several automated reasoning and proof presentation tools with the Mizar system for formalization of mathematics. The combination forms an online service called MizAR, similar to the SystemOnTPTP service for first-order automated reasoning. The main differences to SystemOnTPTP are the use of the Mizar language that is oriented towards human mathematicians (rather than the pure first-order logic used in SystemOnTPTP), and setting the service in the context of the large Mizar Mathematical Library of previous theorems,definitions, and proofs (rather than the isolated problems that are solved in SystemOnTPTP). These differences poses new challenges and new opportunities for automated reasoning and for proof presentation tools. This paper describes the overall structure of MizAR, and presents the automated reasoning systems and proof presentation tools that are combined to make MizAR a useful mathematical service.

sections.heading: 2 SystemOnTPTP
sections.text: The core of SystemOnTPTP is a utility that makes it possible to prepare a problem or solution easily and quickly for a number of systems and tools. SystemOnTPTP uses a number of currently available systems and tools, whose properties (input format, result status, etc.) are stored in a simple text database. Input can be selected from the TPTP (thousands of problems for Theorem Provers) problem library or the TSTP (thousands of solutions for Theorem Provers), or it is provided by the user in TPTP format. Implementation relies on several tools to prepare the execution of the selected system.

sections.heading: 3.5 Getting Hints for Necessary Mizar References
sections.text: If none of the ATP systems can find proof of an ATP problem (which corresponds to a Mizar conclusion), either because the ATP system has a timeout or because it has been determined that the ATP problem is counterproductive (as in Figure 3), then a few additional assumptions (Mizar references) must typically be added to the TPTP problem. The explanation field can provide clues to prove the Mizar proposal by using the link "Suggest hints" that will be inserted into the field if the EP does not find proof (see Figure 3). The button "Suggest hints" is linked to a Bayesian consultant trained on the entire MML (i.e. on all the evidence contained therein). (See [34] for details on how machine learning is organized in the context of a large deductive repository, such as MML. Other axiom selection systems could be used as a sugion server trained in a manner similar to the Web).

sections.heading: 4 Future Work and Conclusions
sections.text: This paper has introduced the MizAR web service, which allows Mizar users to use automated reasoning tools for their Mizar articles. MizAR is, to a certain extent, on and similar to the SystemOnTPTP service for solving first-order problems. The main differences to SystemOnTPTP are evidently the use of the Mizar language, which is oriented toward human mathematicians (and not the pure first-order logic used in SystemOnTPTP), and the discontinuation of the service in the context of the large Mizar Mathematical Library of earlier theorems, definitions, and proofs. There are obvious differences to these systems, which are provided by the large theory implementation in which Mizar formalization is usually carried out. There are several use cases described above, ranging from the use of HTMLization to the disambiguation of complicated Mizar syntax, use of ATP systems to explain Mizar examples, use of counter-examples, and provide counter-evidence for Mizar services.
